post.body: This is a post on my new hub. ~~None of you should be able to see this yet (hopefully).~~

Alright, so everything seems to be in order for my new awesome hub and cleanly migrating hubs for those of you who want to switch to my hub, or the infinity one (or even Red->Blue/Blue->Red for you color traitors).

First things first is to seed the new hub you want to switch to. You're likely already seeding Red and Blue, but you'll need to seed the [Kaffie hub](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv) or the infinity hub, if you want to switch to those. If you're seeing this post, you should already have the Kaffie hub.

Don't bother going to the 'create profile' page. That's for suckers. It's nice to check which subs you're seeding, but the 'create profile' button just messes things up. Instead, go to your home sub (you can figure out what this is by hovering over your name and looking at the URL) and go into the /data/users/[your id]/ folder. You'll want to copy over this whole folder into the new hub's equivalent.

In the destination hub, open up content.json in a text editor (like sublime, so formatting doesn't get messed up). All you want to do is edit 'address' to point to the new hub, instead of your old one.

Next, open up data.json in the destination hub. You'll see all your original hub data. Here's what we're going to do. Delete all of the entries under 'comments'. These are comments relating to the hub they're in, so you don't need them migrated. You should still keep the array though, since that's where all your new hub comments will go.

Change the 'hub' to the new hub you're migrating to. Just like you did in the content.json. This is a reference to say what your 'home hub' is. We'll eventually edit this in EVERY hub you're seeding or posted in, but one step at a time.

Change 'next_comment_id' to 1. Since we deleted the comments, we need to reset the counter.

Here's where you get a choice. There's two options for your posts. Either you can migrate the data, which switches the name link on those posts (and hosts it in the new hub) but also unlink everyone's comments, or you can leave the posts in the old hub, and start fresh. If you start fresh, your old posts will still appear, but they'll link back to your old hub profile. So keep that in mind. I personally started fresh.

To start fresh, do the same thing to your posts as you did your comments. Delete all the entries and change the 'next_post_id' to 1.

Lastly, delete everything under 'post_like'. Keep the array though.

That should set up your new hub account. Now we need to repoint your data on the other hubs. For each hub you've posted in, go into that hub's folder and find your user folder, like we did before.

On each one, open the data.json and simply edit the 'hub' variable to point to your home hub. This is probably optional (as it repoints the comment links), but I went ahead and did it to reduce the amount of problems.

On your original sub, a couple more things need to be tweaked. Delete everything under 'follows'. Remove the variable entirely. Delete 'next_follow_id' as well. Change 'hub' to your new hub, as usual. And if you opted to migrate your posts, delete the entire 'posts' section along with the 'next_post_id' variable. If not, leave it. I didn't migrate, so I left the posts there.

Change the intro to something to notify people to switch the profile they follow. This is technically optional, and you can just delete it if you feel like it. Delete the 'avatar' if you migrated posts (it's unneeded), but if you kept your posts there, then you'll want to keep it, as otherwise your old posts won't have an avatar (perhaps this is preferred?)

Finally, we save up and go to sign/publish our changes. Visit each hub site (the actual site down at the bottom of zerohello, not zerome). Then drag the sidebar open and select 'i own this site'. Put your user content.json in the bottom box (should look something like: data/users/[yourid]/content.json) and hit sign. It'll prompt for a privatekey. Use your ZeroID private key (found at the top of your zeronet's user.json file) and then click publish. Do this for every hub you've edited.

---

So now all of the changes are made and published. Everyone else should see everything just fine. But you might still be stuck logged into your old hub. So delete every hub but your destination hub. Then go into zerome and ensure you're logged in properly. Finally, redownload each hub and everything should be good to go!

Update on the login issue for KaffieID. The login code detects your cert name, which is the little `name@zeroid.bit` and then compares it to the one in your `content.json` file. If they match, it sets that as your user. If not, then it doesn't. So username switching systems, or people with matching names/providers (such as nanasi/kaffie that don't guarantee name uniqueness) you get login issues. And switching an id (even with the same auth keys and such) makes a login issue, despite signing working correctly anyway.

Apparently the only think you need to change is the content.json in your home hub, to fix this. just change `"cert_user_id": "name@provider.bit",` to whatever it is that is in the top right (your cert name). If this field is missing, there'll be issues. And if it doesn't match, there'll be issues.

The fix I posted below (changing the detection in all.js) to be based on auth_address) works as well, and lets you log in regardless (so if your signing is good, you're all set). Though amusingly, the little `name@provider.bit` that appears everywhere *is* based on that field in the content.json. Interesting...

I'd still like the change to all.js to be made though, so that this issue doesn't occur. Having broken logins is never good.

So there's been signing/publishing issues issues with KaffieID and I seem to have found out why. When there's a cert_sign in the content.json, ZeroNet attempts to create a new cert to recreate the cert_sign to verify.

Here's the relevant code:

```
def verifyCert(self, inner_path, content):
        from Crypt import CryptBitcoin

        rules = self.getRules(inner_path, content)
        if not rules.get("cert_signers"):
            return True  # Does not need cert

        name, domain = content["cert_user_id"].split("@")
        cert_address = rules["cert_signers"].get(domain)
        if not cert_address:  # Cert signer not allowed
            self.log.error("Invalid cert signer: %s" % domain)
            return False
        return CryptBitcoin.verify(
            "%s#%s/%s" % (rules["user_address"], content["cert_auth_type"], name), cert_address, content["cert_sign"]
)
```

This means that only certs that have signed using `useraddress#authtype/name` are valid. Which eliminates the ability to change names but keep the same cert. This verification requiring the name is entirely useless, and you can get around the entire issue by modifying the content.json to simply not have a cert_sign.

So... what should we do? Just force everyone to use the `useraddress#authtype/name` and hope that no one pushes out a cert that uses something different? KaffieID uses `useraddress#authtype/kaffie.bit` so that names can freely change. However, that seems to mess up the python verification. The cert works, it's just unexpected due to not using the name. Should I just change KaffieID to mess up certs when you change names? Seems kind of dumb that changing a name for an ID service would mess up your cert. I mean, we already have public/private keys. Is a specialized cert_sign in a particular format that breaks if you change names necessary?

Alternatively we can look a bit further on what's actually going on behind the scenes, and perhaps fix it entirely? Perhaps certs should have a 'format' for the verification to take place?

@nofish: I'm interested to see what you have to say. At the moment the cert_sign appears to me as a redundant check that breaks certs that use different formatting. Why not simply change the check to `useraddress#authtype/signersite`? Is there even a way to change this now that people have been using ZeroIDs? Would the 'format' option I described work?

I really want [ZeroTube](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1FUQPLXHimgCvYHH7v3bJXspJ7bMBUXcEb) to be a success, but no one cares to seed anything... The big issue seems to be that there's no way to get the magnet link/torrent file from a video, meaning you can only ever seed it when you're on the page. And uploading is really glitchy, so if you use the direct thing, you're shit outta luck.

I went ahead and mirrored some videos (Cosmos Laundromat, Fastcast vids, etc) as well as uploaded a new one of my own (Deadpool movie). For those who want to just manually upload stuff, here's my process:

1. Drag/drop the movie into webtorrent. This is to start the seeding process. Don't include anything besides the mp4. Webms don't work, and I'm guessing stuff like AVIs don't work either.

2. Right click on the newly seeded torrent and hit 'copy magnet link'. You'll paste this in the 'magnet' field on your data.json.

3. Add a new video in your data.json. Here's the format:

```
{
"video_id": "",
"title": "",
"description": "",
"magnet": "",
"date_added": ""
}
```

For 'video_id', it's expecting the bittorrent hash listed under 'bith'. It's in the magnet link near the beginning. For date_added, my new entries have the format `2016-08-29T02:12:14.588Z`. (Edit: You can use [this site](http://www.unixtimestamp.com/) to generate a timestamp. Use the 'ISO 8601' one.)

Have fun. Still no way to increase the seeds besides manually sharing the magnet link and downloading through webtorrent (or staying on the page). You can grab a video's magnet link in the same manner. Alternatively you can grab the bith from the end of the watching URL, and paste that right into webtorrent desktop.

And remember, the more support ZeroTube gets, the more webtorrents are seeded for *any* webtorrent video service. So let's work together to kickstart a solid video streaming platform for ZeroNet :D

Edit: Help mirror youtube videos by pasting the url into this site http://keepvid.com/ and then hitting the 'Download MP4 - 720p' option.

Obamaphone finally came. Immediately put the sim into my Moto G4 and it worked out of the box for talk/text. Data took some messing about and worked after rebooting the phone.

The provided smart phone is a Fuego 4.0D by "Sky Devices'. Box says it has a 2.0mp camera on both front and back, 512mb storage, 256mb ram. Stuck on Android 4.4 Kitkat. I personally like the light blue accents on the phone, makes it look cute :3.

For data, it's displaying LTE and speed test resulted in 1mbps down, 4mbps up. Though that might just be because I'm in a crappy area. It's apparently using T-Mobile network, which has never worked great where I live.

Contrary to the advertisement on the front page of the tag mobile site, the account info is showing limited talk/text/data, that *did* decrease after using. I dunno if it was a fluke, or if that's honestly how much I get. Lists 2gb 'data' (whether it's 3g or lte who knows), ~135 minutes, and ~8000 sms for the month.

So yeah... I'm in the smartphone club now :P. Talk/text/data are all working fine on my Moto phone. The obamaphone itself boots and runs. Has the play store and works fine.

Oh, if you note the picture, you can see the card that had the sim in it. It's a *full sized* sim card, and was already removed and stuck in the obamaphone itself. My Moto required the one size smaller version of the sim, so I merely popped out the sim and it worked fine.

People should start uploading dropbox-webseeded video torrents onto KopyKate. It's definitely possible. There's a tutorial written up somewhere, but perhaps I'll just upload a video to show it like I did with ZeroTube that one time. It's not *really* decentralized (it's more like a dropbox video streaming site lol), but it's what's needed to get things kickstarted. I wonder what a better way of having decentralized webseeds would be?

Went ahead and uploaded [another video on KopyKate.](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1aCq7GiJfUfGZ4GftjYaYbsEngPFzcxvN/?Topic:8_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh/Yosuga+no+Sora+OP) This time I wanted to try a new webseed method, [Peerify](https://peerify.btorrent.xyz/). With dropbox gone, we really need a reliable webseed if we want P2P video sharing to take off. I'm not sure how long Peerify hosts videos for, so that's the point of this test. I've moved all my videos over for now, instead of just having me seed them 24/7. Hopefully this works better.

I've also been trying to figure out how to rip video from [Bitchute](https://www.bitchute.com/) which relies on webtorrent and uses it's own webseeding server. However, there seems to be a CORS restriction or something that messes up the webseeding for anyone else. Kind of defeats the purpose of having it a torrent if no one else can help share the video. Amusingly, popping in the link into webtorrent desktop lets it stream just fine. So maybe it's a ZeroNet issue?

Either way, I hope people *finally* start uploading some videos. The process is *real* simple now. Just upload your video on Peerify, copy the link, and paste that in KopyKate, being sure that the uploaded link is the .torrent, rather than the converted magnet link. From there, you can personally help seed by copying the KopyKate magnet into your own webtorrent desktop app.

Also, if anyone knows about other places that are big users of webtorrent, please mention where you saw it, as we can piggyback off their content.

Now that the login is working, [ZeroNet Central](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1J1c7eML6uMwDU4uiKbKRxoqxGP6WMFMvb) seems like a pretty good site. Gives a really close feel to reddit/voat, which is nice. Looks like I'm no longer using namecoin. I'd recommend everyone do the same. Namecoin no longer has a working mac build for the wallet, meaning I'm unable to access my coins or domains. As a result, my domains expired and were scalped by scammers.

I'll be moving all of my zites away from using domain names. Though, the scalpers were nice enough to keep the domains pointed at my zites. So they'll work for the foreseeable future until they're sold/used/expired&renewed/etc.

Besides that, I don't have an income so I wouldn't be able to afford to keep doing it. And Namecoin also puts a sort of centralization on ZN, and requires connection to the current internet in order to function properly. These also contributed to my decision to stop using namecoin entirely.

It's a cute system to help give domain names to ZN sites, but this isn't the solution. Tor Onion Addresses don't need names, so why should ZN sites? Links and portals seem good enough to get the job done, along with a customizeable display name for your homepage.

Reserving a particular word for a particular website seems to be a flawed system in general, and just promotes a need to have a way of providing ownership over tokens. Which isn't something I'd like to support.

---

What does this mean for ZeroNet and my network of sites? Ideally y'all shouldn't notice a difference unless you're directly typing my site names into your browser. The clickable links on ZeroHello will naturally change to remove the domain name. Things using the domain name are: the cert ID "create a KaffieID" link will break if the domain is repointed. Any links using the names will break if the domain is repointed. And.... that's about it.

Thank you all for your continued support. Let's try and build a better web together :)

Went ahead and set up the IDName plugin found [here.](https://github.com/geekless/ZeroNet/tree/IDName/plugins/IDName) It assigns [certname].zeroid addresses to the auth_address of that cert. So something like [kaffie.zeroid](http://127.0.0.1:43110/kaffie.zeroid) will go to my auth address at http://zero/1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh. Obviously your private key for your cert works for signing that site. So I went ahead and mirrored the kaffie.bit site over to it along with added a section for subdomains. So search.kaffie.zeroid will redirect to kaffiene, and blog.kaffie.zeroid will navigate to my blog.

Really cool stuff and it instantly solves the domain name problem; at least for cert providers with unique names that are publicly viewable. Naturally this won't work for something like KaffieID, as there's no registry of addresses, and no unique names.

Found out there's a third type of "deepfake" that I hadn't really known about. The underlying tech is actually a bit unrelated and is called "pix2pix". Essentially what it does is it takes in a source template, and a pre-made learned style data, and applies the style to the source. So for instance you can make artwork into different styles, or make complete photo-realistic drawings out of a quick sketch. Or the more terrifying application: make photos of people look like other photos of people.

I had seen things like https://thispersondoesnotexist.com/ https://www.thiscatdoesnotexist.com/ and https://www.thiswaifudoesnotexist.net/ but I never really thought past the implications of it. I saw the *video* versions of this sort of thing (applying a source content to a premade video style) but didn't really realize a generative version for photos could work.

There is also full body generation ( https://datagrid.co.jp/all/release/386/ ).

So here's the scary part, such technology can be used to change clothing style or effectively create nudes of people. So sort of like the oldest deepfake tech, but in reverse. Instead of swapping the face you're swapping the clothes. IE stripping the person in the photo. So naturally I was horribly curious and it was kinda easy to set up for me. And I got to work taking pics of myself seeing what the extent was and how far it could go. I also tried some professional shots in various stages of undress, along with some amateur photos (to test low quality).

And the results are kinda..... mixed. Things like professional photoshoots in bikinis and light clothing work shockingly well, though there's some artifacting (you can tell its a fake in every case). In certain cases, both amateur and professional, the quality was well above what I've seen certain porn end up at, and the results looked realistic.

It *also* worked quite well even for people fully clothed. It was able to remove things like leggings but having notable blur/distortion along the legs. Shorts and t-shirts were removed fine. For tops it worked best with midriff showing, rather than having it covered up (it uses the navel to help align/detect). Long tops (tunics and such), dresses, and skirts all obscure the pelvic area and as a result have poor results, especially if the naval is also covered.

My own photos.... didn't go so well. My fully clothed photos ended up horribly disorted or improperly detected (my camera is low quality and I dress modestly). One photo I was wearing a t-shirt and jeans and it properly stripped, ending up with blurred legs, along with some distortion on the added nudity. Trying in underwear it ends up removing panties, but it was having difficulties with my bra, and worked better if I removed that entirely (ie just having it remove panties). It altered my breast size and never actually detected it properly, though it matched my and others' skin tone properly in every photo. Though some of the photos I took from online were altered as if there was a color filter over it.

TL;DR: Despite this seeming scary, it's actually not that bad. Just avoid skin-tight clothes and anything revealing (ie swimwear/undies). Though in the future this could be horrifying, specifically if it becomes popular or widespread. Especially since on my crappy old laptop the photos took less than a minute to create.

@Bot: On the 'post on my hub', that's because you clicked 'join hub' without migrating your user data. So you have two profiles. One of which is on my hub. Namely we need a way to easily manage the 'hub' variable, as well as use that solely for identifying which hub you're on. At the moment, it doesn't seem to work like that, and causes problems.

Cross-hub posting works fine, the comments are placed in the hub you're commenting in like they should. If your comments on my hub were placed in a different hub, I wouldn't be able to see them.

In reality, what we need is a profile page being determined solely by the 'hub' variable, and the posts to be fetched from a 'posted hubs' list (like a new variable listing the hubs you've posted in. This list would be fetched from the home hub.). I think that'd solve all the problems.

Edit: As it is now, the URL defines which hub to load for your profile. That's a huge mistake, as going to the wrong hub would cause problems.

@P2P: Actually, likes are properly sorted by their hub, and correctly refer to the post_id. The issue is that the likes don't mention a hub at all, and the software ignores which hub they came from, and apply it to any post with the same post_id. Likes don't need an id, because you can't like a like. Meaning that you don't actually need to find one.

Comments are the same way, but since comments can be on multiple hubs (posts are only ever on your home hub), the comments are correctly placed under the appropriate hub/post_id

@P2P: The backend supports it cleanly. All the data is properly structured to make it a simple swap. I more or less migrated perfectly by hand. It's the ZeroMe frontend that causes the issues. Since it glitches with posts from multiple hubs (easy fix is to just check the hubs). And it also relies on the url to determine which hub your login/posts are in, which causes glitches (again, easy fix, just use the 'hub' variable in literally every hub data folder). That, and there's no 'migrate hub' button. Instead there's just a 'join hub', which deletes some data and such, and obviously that messes things up. It also doesn't switch the hub variable, or fix other things that could cause glitches.

After those two things are fixed (in the ZeroMe site itself), then it should work fine. A ZeroMe clone could certainly be used for clean migrations. Amusingly, the old zerome would still support the migrated account, due to how things work. But it'd still run into the same glitches as it is now (duplicate likes, login issues, following old profiles, etc.).

@P2P: Yea, I wrote out what happens. People's comments/likes are posted in the hub they're connected to. So if you 'migrate posts', the comments no longer properly link. A proper account migration would leave the comments there, and correctly distinguish between posts made on different hubs. If you're censored on a hub, you can only migrate *your* content (comments and posts). Not anyone else's.

>"IMO, comments (posted by others) and likes should be in the sub folder of the user, which makes the user can control all of the comments and likes,"

Comments and likes are posted on the appropriate hub that they refer to. I imagine that was by design, so that red hub users can see posts made on the red hub. Otherwise, you'd have to have every hub to see people's comments. Unless you meant comments posted by others going into your (OP) folder. Which is impossible, due to the way that ZeroNet authentication works. There's no way to touch another user's content. Period.

At best we keep it how it is, but correct the posts linkage issue (by relating comments/likes to same hub posts, and make a user's profile only ever link back to what's listed in the 'hub' entry).

>"All my comments posted to sub folder of an user in other hubs should be also backuped to my profile's hub and backup hubs in case of something unexpected happen."

I wasn't even aware this was a possibility. The only issue I can see here is that other people's comments would increase your folder size and more quickly reach your cap. But it *is* a good solution for migrating comments as well.

Copy+pasting the fix for attention:

on line 4842 (in the 'checkuser' function) there's an SQL query. I changed it *from*

` "SELECT * FROM json WHERE cert_user_id = :cert_user_id AND user_name IS NOT NULL AND file_name = 'data.json'"`

and changed it *to*

`"SELECT * FROM json WHERE directory='data/users/"+this.site_info.auth_address+"' AND user_name IS NOT NULL AND file_name = 'data.json'"`

The issue was that it wasn't ever picking up my kaffieid account, because there was some cert_user_id problems. I changed it to instead point to the directory entry to determine user login. Since that's how it assumes it works anyway. Basing it on a mystical cert_user_id (essentially your cert username) is a bad idea, since it might not always be in the database (like mine wasn't).

KaffieID is just added to the drop down selector thing when you log in. You can easily switch between the two by clicking the 'yourname@zeroid.bit' in the top-right and then selecting which you want to use.

Hmm... It looks like you either didn't follow my switching hubs guides completely/correctly. Or you you clicked 'join hub' when you weren't supposed to. So now you have two duplicate sets of data on infinity hub and kaffie hub.

To fix this, just take either one (whichever one you don't want to be on) and then remove these fields from your data.json:

"next_post_id": #,

"next_follow_id": #,

"avatar": "generate",

"intro": "description",

"post": [ {some posts} ]

"follow": [ {some follows} ]

And then change this field to match the hub you didn't remove/edit:

"hub": "hubaddress you want to stay on",

After that, just sign/publish, or make a comment/like on the hub you erased.

Upon further thinking, the hardcoded format was likely an oversight by nofish in an attempt to keep usernames unique. Only give out certs with a unique name on the backend. And on the front end have verification that includes the name in the cert. It'd prevent people from just manually changing their ZeroID name as it'd fail to sign.

So perhaps just eliminating it is not the best way to go about things. I still personally think the format option is best. As some users may want to change their username but still retain access to their content. At the moment, this requires using a name-agnostic signer like Kaffiene, and then deleting the 'cert_sign' and 'cert_auth' fields in the content.json manually. This seems particularly non userfriendly for no real reason.

Umm... Yea, the cert_sign with the name is entirely useless, given I was able to do this: http://127.0.0.1:43110/talk.zeronetwork.bit/?Topic:11_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh

Why bother with cert_sign if we can just delete it and move on without it? I was able to spoof nofish@zeroid.bit on ZeroTalk. So clearly names are guaranteed not unique. All one has to do is change the name and delete cert_sign.

This is a huge flaw for anything that expects unique usernames. Seems like a waste of time to have something that limits user-ability when you can manually work around it.

@Talnicrom: Your zeronet isn't rejecting it, because I removed the cert_sign. See the code above. It just returns true if it's missing. It's definitely a bug. Either the cert_sign is needed, and the skip needs to be removed. Or it isn't and it shouldn't be there.

As for the 'useraddress#authtype/useraddress' that won't work. It explicitly has to be 'useraddress#authtype/name' otherwise zeronet will reject it. Technically I didn't have to include anything. I could've easily signed with just 'useraddress#authtype'. I simply added the singersite to make it distinguishably different from KaffieID clones.

I'm unsure of which way we should proceed. Forcing users to keep the same name to ensure the cert_sign is the same is dumb. It's not required at all (signs can be verified with just authaddress and authtype). I'm still entirely unsure of the purpose of including it. Why not just remove it from the content.json?

The files won't be accepted anyway if you don't have the user's private key. So ensuring that the authtype/authaddress/name is the same seems pointless.

@Talnicrom: Sorry, to clarify: The name itself is indeed useful for displaying a name of some sort. The original implementation was an attempt to keep this unique (hence ZeroID). Everything is signed according to auth_address and your private key.

Certificates have a few things to distinguish them: the site it's issued from, the user's public and private key. The type of authentication. The username, and the cert_sign. The cert_sign is reconstructed on each users' machine following the formula given. And then compared to the one included in content.json (which is a copy of the one that the site provides). However, there's no guarantee the site will use said formula, and thus the publish is rejected despite having the private key correct.

To bypass this, you remove the auth_type and cert_sign provided in the content.json. Now that these are lacking, the cert_sign check is skipped and it just verifies that the private key was used and signed the stuff correctly.

So the cert_sign is entirely unneeded. It can be removed manually, and doesn't help authenticate anything. So I'm wondering why bother having it? And if it remains, why not allow a formula config, so that non-unique name services can exist?

@P2P: Not that serious of a bug, tbh. AFAIK there's no way to abuse this to compromise security. It just bypasses the unique name thing. Users are still uniquely identifiable with their auth_address. If you hover over the nofish spoof, you'll see my auth_address, which has remained the same this entire time. So you can tell who the 'real' nofish is by that. It's just a serious bug for username uniqueness since it completely bypasses the backend stuff to guarantee unique names. I can't actually edit/change/be nofish with this :P.

@Krixano: The auth_address and auth_private key are generated per-site and are used for ID sites like ZeroID.bit or KaffieID. Some sites also use them to make 'anonymous' or per-site logins. They are unique per user per site.

@Peeper: ZeroID verifies name uniqueness by using a backend server and keeping the site signer private key hidden. KaffieID makes the key public, removing name uniqueness, but also removing the reliance on a back end server. They're two different ID sites. So you need the site to specifically accept ZeroIDs or KaffieIDs. Most sites just accept ZeroID, so KaffieID isn't really that useful yet besides just a proof of concept.

@Musickiller: There's more strict cross-origin blocking, which kills a method I use to fetch files from the same+other sites. So here's a list of things I worked on that have broke because of this new update:

* ZeroWiki support on Kaffiene
* Other site indexes on Kaffiene
* Every index besides basic searching on Kaffiene (though local indexes will come back soon)
* ZeroMovie's frame escape
* http://zero/ protocol testing on Kaffie.bit

@空澄砂夜: There's a few options:

1. Leave old content the way it is. The profile links will link back to the old profile, which used to cause problems, but not much anymore.

2. Move the posts to the new hub. However, the old comments will be orphaned and no longer viewable. You can either migrate your own (removing context), delete them, or leave them be.

3. Delete the posts entirely. This will orphan the old comments. Your comments could either be deleted or just left to be orphaned.

1 is the safest option, as it lets everything be the way it was. However, there's still some 'bad' links. The severity is less now though, with the newer updates of ZeroMe. 2 is the cleanest. It lets you keep your old posts, and thus have a history of what you've actually done. While also fixing links and such. However, other users' content is now gone (and just left taking up space). 3 is nice if you just want to start over lol.

Edit: If you move the posts the old comments aren't 'deleted'. You can't delete other peoples' comments. They're just unviewable due to not having a parent post (since you moved it to a different hub).

@Krixano: Right. Ideally you should *display* as the cert_user_id, and *manage* using the auth_address. If you're only ever going to accept ZeroIDs, then it doesn't matter, but technically speaking, there's nothing guaranteeing that ZeroIDs are unique, except for nofish's private backend server. @Nekololi: An emoticon is a collection of text to form an image out of words. Think :D or :(. An emoji is a unicode character that's specified to be a particular image. Stuff like 😀 or 😺 is an emoji.

Basically, if you need to use a special keyboard or character entry (for like apple/android/etc smilies/images) then it's an emoji, if you can type it with a regular qwerty keyboard, it's an emoticon.

Though when you start going back, the two get kind of fuzzy. The Docomo emoji were meant to *replace* emoticons which were popular in Japan. So a lot of their emoji actually look like emoticons (albeit upright).

Emoticons can basically be written in any font. An emoji font drastically changes what an emoji actually looks like (see: iOS vs Android for a big difference).

@Krixano: Revisiting ZeroID will regenerate your user cert. So if you're only going off a master seed then you need to. If you simply copied over your users.json file then there's no need.

auth_address and auth_privatekey are generated per site. The one connected to the ID site is used as the base for the cert. Basically, these are how content is signed for the user.

Those, the username, and the auth_type are used by the signer to generate a cert for the user, and is then checked when the user posts.

@leftside: Not that I'm aware of. It's pretty simple. Just imagine it as a front end and a back end. The front end "me.zeronetwork.bit" site is essentially your "browser" for zerome. It runs the logic of the site. Whereas the hubs (which you don't directly visit, redhub, bluehub, kaffiehub, etc) just store all of the posts/images/data. The hub data is then "viewed" in the front end site.

@leftside: The reason hubs are used is so that the data is distributed/decentralized, and separate from the viewing frontend. Say nofish goes insane and decides to be a nazi mod or something on ZeroTalk. Then we basically just have to give up the site and go somewhere else. Loss. He has full control over the site and things posted on it.

With ZeroMe that isn't the case. He controls his own hub (most of the default ones), while I control my own. So if he went nazi mod here on ZeroMe, all of my content is safe. He can't touch it. He *can* touch the front-end site which I use, but if that happens I can hop over to some other ZeroMe frontend site and continue enjoying zerome without any influence from nofish. And others using both his nazimodded hub and front-end can still see my posts and interact with me.

People are basically free to run their own data hub and front-end, so they can be completely liberated, while also being a part of the larger community. Win-Win. You don't get this with ZeroTalk.

What you could do (I haven't seen it done yet), is do the same thing with ZeroTalk. Make the data the hub backend and then make the viewer a merger site. So that the posts are all safe and stored on various hubs controlled by different people, and people could use whatever forum viewer they wanted.

Don't like ZeroMe's layout? Easy to swap it out. Don't like ZeroTalk's layout? You're fucked.

I think the issue will be resolved naturally given two things:
1. Suggested mute lists by default. Similar to how adblock programs have lists that are auto-suggested/configured. And have mute lists *prevent downloading* of the muted user's content (this is key).

2. Have more sites, and not funnel all new users into the same handful of sites. This will reduce the size of the target. As of now, if zerotalk gets spammed, that's the only place people chat so it makes it a mess. But if there were hundreds of different forums, all given equal weight? Well then one forum spammed isn't a huge issue (it's only an issue for that forum).

And with spamming basically being futile in a larger system, the incentive will naturally decrease. At least, that's the theory. So combining those two will likely solve the problem (and does for people who don't really care to spam other than some basic shitposting).

ZeroNet does authorization through a public-private key system. ID providers associate the public key with a username/site. Normally this relies on a centralized back-end server to guarantee username uniqueness. However with KaffieID I just have the site's key publicly on the site, so they can sign their cert themselves, allowing any name to be signed without guarantee of uniqueness. This gives it the benefit of being able to be used in an entirely decentralized manner.

It's possible to simply have the same solution per-site, but that eliminates the convenience of a single address per user, along with makes it difficult to have consistency between sites. It also adds more work for site devs.

Adding KaffieID support is identical to adding ZeroID support (and you can support both very easily). So it makes everything very convenient. KaffieID itself is cloneable as well, in case you want to use something else that's similar.

Technically speaking, KaffieID is entirely unneeded if ZeroNet would allow creating and direct posting from auth-addresses without needing a cert provider. Things like bitcoin and other cryptocurrency do just that. But I think it's nice that it has a name attached as well. All in all it's meant as an easy system to give a fully decentralized ID provider to ZeroNet.

>Does .bit mean a single point of failure?

Yes. Like all blockchains, namecoin is prone to a centralization of invested wealthy parties, and a reliance on centralized internet infrastructure. Any system that guarantees name uniqueness suffers from this problem. For example if we turned zeroids into domains (which is actually a thing that has been done in the past). There's still a centralized manner of guaranteeing names are unique. Non-legible names (the raw addresses) are unique but lack legibility. This is a known problem of decentralization. The .bit fetching of names is done on your local machine, as it fetches it from the zeroname website (which has a centralized backend that updates from namecoin). You can configure zeronet to use a local instance of namecoin, if you prefer it.

>if i promote my site by mentioning its .bit address and then will not renew the .bit name, people will fail to access my site and many will NOT even find the zite "internal"/real address 

ZN is currently configured so that if the namecoin domain expires, the registry still maintains the entry until someone else purchases the name and uses it for a new ZN site. This is happened to my network of sites. My domains expired and were immediately bought by others, but not ZN users, so the names still point to my site, but without my control.

>From decentralization and distributed point of view it appear to me like it is better NOT to use .bit name and promote site with internal address like 127.0.0.1:43110/15psKMf7iWZNdos5iKNQRTwu31hXEM9gFi ?

Yes, that's the ideal, though it's a bit inelegant. If someone visits your site through the .bit, its stored via the actual raw address. So if your name is compromised, you can just instruct your site to not rely on it, and users will still have your site accessible via the raw address.

>If there are any work arounds? I appreaciate if you explain it. Thank You

No. There's a plugin for ZN that allow you to use zeroid names as domain names. Since your zeroid is unique and tied to a particular address, you can make a DNS registry on that address to get subdomains. This avoids a centralized blockchain, but relies on a uniqueness-guaranteed ID provider (which in tern requires a centralized backend).

As mentioned, hubs contain the actual data of what you're looking at. IE user posts. So all of my posts here on zeronet (other than comments) are stored on kaffiehub. If you do not have kaffiehub downloaded, you won't see what I'm posting. Likewise if you only have kaffiehub, you won't see what people on sun hub are posting. If you want to view *all* of the posts on zerome, you need *all* of the hubs. However, due to the decentralized nature of zeronet, it's simply impossible to magically know what all of the hubs are. And it's impossible to connect to users who may user zeronet offline on their lan. Meaning you'd never even be able to connect to some zerome hubs.

This is the nature of decentralized communication platforms. You can never be quite sure you've seen everything, as there's no central source to check whether you've seen it all. But yes, download as many hubs as possible if you want to see as much content as possible. http://127.0.0.1:43110/0hub.bit is a zite that auto-downloads many of the known hubs for you.
